ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Band offsets of
Er 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Er}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ films grown on Ge substrates by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Advanced Transducers and Intelligent Control System (Ministry of Education), College of Physics and Optoelectronics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
The band alignments of high-k Er2O3 films grown on Ge substrates by molecular beam epitaxy are determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The valence-band and the conduction-band offsets of Er2O3 to Ge are found to be
3.16 ± 0.02
$3.16\pm0.02$ and
2.13 ± 0.02
eV
$2.13\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ , respectively. The energy gap of Er2O3 is
5.96 ± 0.02
eV
$5.96\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ as determined by the optical spectrophotometry. From the band offset viewpoint, the above results indicate that Er2O3 could be a promising candidate for high-k gate dielectrics on Ge substrate.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Due to its high carrier mobility Ge is an attractive candidate for manufacturing complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) elements and metal insulator semiconductor (MIS) devices. However, because of its cost and the instability of its oxide, historically Ge is left behind as compared to Si. Recently, as the fabrication of high-k oxide materials on Si becomes feasible [1], much research efforts have been devoted to the deposition of high-k oxide films on Ge substrates [2–5]. Nevertheless, the devices fabricated on Ge substrates often suffer from large leakage currents [6]. As we know, the gate leakage current mechanism for insulator films includes direct tunneling and Fowler–Nordheim (F-N) tunneling. For sufficiently thick gate dielectric films, the leakage current is dominated by F-N tunneling, which depends exponentially on the barrier height [7]. Therefore, it is important to choose a high-k material with a large band gap as well as a sufficiently large offset to Ge for both valence and conduction bands to guarantee a sufficiently high barrier height for both holes and electrons and hence a low leakage current.

Er2O3 high-k dielectric has been reported to have large valence-band offset (VBO) and conduction-band offset (CBO) on Si substrates [8], therefore being a promising gate candidate on Si substrates. It is necessary to evaluate whether Er2O3 is a suitable gate insulator on Ge substrates. However, up to now, the experimental and calculation data about the band offsets of Er2O3 on Ge have not been reported. In this work, the band gap of Er2O3, VBO and CBO between the Er2O3 films and Ge substrates is determined by optical spectrophotometry and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The results show the offsets of the VBO and CBO to be
3.16 ± 0.02
$3.16\pm0.02$ and
2.13 ± 0.02
eV
$2.13\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ , respectively, suggesting the feasibility of Er2O3 film on Ge for MOS application.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
Er2O3 films were deposited in a molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) system using metallic Er and molecular oxygen sources with a pressure of about
1 ×
10
− 3
Pa
$1\times10^{- 3}\ \mathrm{Pa}$ at room temperature. P-type Ge (001) substrates (1.5 inch in diameter) with resistivity of
< 1
Ω
cm
${<} 1\ \Omega \,\mbox{cm}$ were initially cleaned by diluted HF and then loaded into the growth chamber. In situ Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) results indicated that the films were stoichiometric with an atomic ratio of 1.5 for O to Er. Another sample was grown on the quartz substrate to perform the optical measurement with the same deposition conditions in MBE.

The film is about 5.5-nm-thick as measured by the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The ex situ XPS measurements were carried out in a Thermo ESCALAB 250 equipment with Al
K α
$\mathrm{K} \alpha$ (
h ν = 1486.6
eV
$h \nu = 1486.6\ \mbox{eV}$ ) radiation as the excitation of photoelectrons. All scans were taken in normal emission geometry with pass energy of 20 eV. The binding energy scale was calibrated with pure gold, silver and copper. The absorption spectrum was obtained by the ultraviolet (UV)-visible spectrophotometer in the wavelength range of 190–500 nm.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para: XPS can be used to determine the band alignment of dielectric/semiconductor heterostructure as the energy difference between the valence-band (VB) edge and the core-level peak for substrate is invariable with/without the deposition of oxide film [9]. This method has been widely used to calculate the band alignments of the insulator/semiconductor and semiconductor/semiconductor heterostructures [10–12]. Therefore, the VB and core-level spectra of the Ge 3p peak from Ge substrate can be used as reference to align the VB and core-level spectra of Er2O3 gate dielectrics overlayer to determine the value of VBO at the Er2O3/Ge interface.

Figure 1 shows the VB and core-level spectra of Ge 3p with and without Er2O3 gate dielectric layer. The leading edge of the VB for clean Ge substrate was measured to be
0.02 ± 0.02
eV
$0.02\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ , as determined by the intersection of the regression-determined line segments defining the edge and the flat energy distribution curve in the energy gap region, as shown in Fig. 1(a). Figure 1(b) is the Ge 3p spectrum of clean Ge substrate. The locations of Ge
3
p
1 / 2
$3\mathrm{p}_{1/2}$ and
3
p
3 / 2
$3\mathrm{p}_{3/2}$ doublets were determined to be 126 and 121.8 eV, respectively. The energy difference between the VB edge and the Ge
3
p
3 / 2
$3\mathrm{p}_{3/2}$ peak was determined to be 121.78 eV for clean Ge(001) substrate. For Ge with Er2O3 overlayer, the thickness of Er2O3 oxide layer is only about 5.5 nm as shown in Fig. 2. As the escape length of Ge
3
p
3 / 2
$3\mathrm{p}_{3/2}$ photoelectron with the kinetic energy of 1364.8 eV can be up to 10 nm, the information from both the film and the substrate can be detected at the same time. The Ge 3p peak from Ge substrate can be observed and is used to align the corresponding VB spectrum as shown in Fig. 1(d). The VB edge of Er2O3 was determined to be
3.18 ± 0.02
eV
$3.18\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ . Therefore, the VBO at the Er2O3/Ge interface is determined to be
3.16 ± 0.02
eV
$3.16\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ by simple subtraction. It should be noted that there is no obvious observation of Ge oxide from Ge 3p spectra, indicating that no Ge oxide formed at the interface. The absence of Ge oxide is also evident in the HRTEM image.

The band gap of Er2O3 was measured by the UV-visible spectrophotometry. Figure 3 shows the absorption coefficient for the Er2O3 films grown on quartz substrate. Relations between the energy gap and absorption can be written as the following equation, proposed by Tauc [13, 14]: 1
α h ν
= B ( h ν −
E g
) ,
$$ \sqrt{\alpha h\nu} = B(h\nu - E_{\mathrm{g}}), $$ where
α
$\alpha$ is the absorption coefficient,
h ν
$h \nu$ is the photon energy,
B
$B$ is a constant and
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ is the optical gap. Tauc’s theory shows that
( α h ν )
1 / 2
$(\alpha h\nu)^{1/2}$ is proportional to
h ν
$h \nu$ for a non-metallic material. Therefore, the optical gap
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ of the films can be evaluated from the x-intercept for linear segment of the plot
( α h ν )
1 / 2
$(\alpha h\nu)^{1/2}$ against the photon energy
h ν
$h \nu$ . By this way,
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ of the Er2O3 film is determined to be
5.96 ± 0.02
eV
$5.96\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ . Band gap of Er2O3 has been studied by several groups. Dakhel measured the
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ of polycrystalline Er2O3 to be 5.3 eV [15]. Singh and Shivashankar reported the
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ of polycrystalline Er2O3 thin films grown by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition as 5.7 eV [16]. And the
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ of the polycrystalline Er2O3 reported by Hagary et al. was 5.86 eV [17]; while of the single crystalline Er2O3 film reported by Zhu et al. it was 7.6 eV, obtained by the O 1s loss spectrum [8]. The
E g
$E_{\mathrm{g}}$ value of Er2O3 we obtained is close to those of the polycrystalline Er2O3 films but much different from those of the single crystalline Er2O3 films. The Er2O3 film we fabricated is also polycrystalline as indicated by the HRTEM image (Fig. 2). Therefore, the difference of energy gap is mainly due to the different microstructures. In addition, different electronic states of the film induced by different growth conditions may also cause the variation of energy gap [17].

The CBO can be obtained by simply subtracting the VBO and the energy gap of the substrate from the band gap of Er2O3: 2
Δ
E c
=
E
gEr 2
O 3
− Δ
E v
−
E gGe
,
$$ \Delta E_{\mathrm{c}} =E_{\mathrm{gEr}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}}-\Delta E_{\mathrm{v}}-E_{\mathrm{gGe}}, $$ where
Δ
E c
$\Delta E_{\mathrm{c}}$ is CBO,
E
gEr 2
O 3
$E_{\mathrm{gEr}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}}$ is the band gap of Er2O3,
Δ
E v
$\Delta E_{\mathrm{v}}$ is the VBO and
E gGe
$E_{\mathrm{gGe}}$ is the band gap of Ge, as shown in Fig. 4. As we know, band gap of Ge is 0.67 eV at room temperature [7]. Therefore, from Eq. (2), the CBO at the interface of Er2O3/Ge is determined to be
2.13 ± 0.02
eV
$2.13\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ .

Schematic energy band alignment diagram for a
Er 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Er}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ /Ge heterostructure

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
The energy-band alignment for the interface of Er2O3/Ge has been studied by XPS. The band gap of Er2O3 determined by UV-visible spectrophotometry is
5.96 ± 0.02
eV
$5.96\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ . The VBO and CBO at the interface of Er2O3/Ge are determined to be
3.16 ± 0.02
$3.16\pm0.02$ and
2.13 ± 0.02
eV
$2.13\pm0.02\ \mbox{eV}$ , respectively. Suitable band gap and large band offset values relative to Ge indicate that Er2O3 may be a promising candidate for high-k gate dielectrics.
